539650.description: Developing non-mathematical critical reasoning skills, including recognition of arguments, argument evaluation and construction of arguments.

539651.title: Introduction to Logic
539651.description: Logical structure of language and correct reasoning: deduction, induction, scientific reasoning and informal fallacies.

539652.title: Religions of the World
539652.description: Introduction to at least five religious world views from an historical and comparative perspective, with descriptive analyses of their belief systems, moral codes and symbolic rituals: Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism and Sikhism. (RLST 110 and PHIL 110 are same course.)

539653.title: Introduction to Ethics
539653.description: Problems of human conduct and moral evaluation: standards for moral assessment of conduct and persons; morality and its relation to mores, social demands and personal commitments.

540750.title: Video Games, the Arts and Philosophy
540750.description: Introduction to art, visual art, games and game theory. Aesthetics of games and interactive visual media. Epistemic and moral relations of virtual worlds to reality. Ultimate value of game-play and visual arts to life’s meaning and purpose.

539654.title: History of Philosophy: Greek Philosophy
539654.description: Origins of Western philosophy and its development through Socrates, Plato and Aristotle.

539655.title: History of Philosophy: Medieval Philosophy
539655.description: Study of philosophies from Late Antiquity through the Renaissance and Reformation. Topics include: Hellenistic philosophy, Scholasticism, and rise of Christian, Jewish, and Islamic philosophy. Figures include: Plotinus, Augustine, Maimonides, Avicenna, Catherine of Siena, Thomas Aquinas, and William of Ockham.

539656.title: History of Philosophy: Rationalism and Empiricism
539656.description: Rationalism of Descartes, Spinoza and Leibniz, and the empiricism of Locke, Berkeley and Hume.

539657.title: History of Philosophy: Kant and the 19th Century
539657.description: Rationalism and empiricism as a background to Kant. Revolutionary aspects of Kant’s critical philosophy. Subsequent trends in 19th century philosophy, emphasizing such figures as Hegel, Schopenhauer, Marx, Mill, Kierkegaard and Nietzsche.

539658.title: Introduction to Women’s Studies
539658.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to women’s issues and research in relevant disciplines. (WGST 302 and PHIL 302 are the same course.)

539659.title: Introduction to the Philosophy of Science
539659.description: The ongoing debates within philosophy of science about the claims of scientific progress, and the limits of scientific knowledge and the scientific method, with an eye on the impact of science on society and of society on science.

539660.title: Aesthetics: Philosophy of Art and Beauty
539660.description: Conditions and aims of art and of aesthetic experience.

539661.title: Business and Professional Ethics
539661.description: Nature and limits of the moral rights and responsibilities of business and the professions (including law, medicine, science, engineering, journalism, management and teaching).

539662.title: Environmental Ethics
539662.description: Conceptual and moral foundations of environmental ethics, focusing on ecosystem and wildlife conservation policies, animal rights, a land ethic, competing policy analyses and obligations to future generations.

539663.title: Medical Ethics
539663.description: Ethical issues raised by recent technical developments in medicine and of the moral rights and responsibilities of patients and health-care professionals.

539664.title: Philosophical Argument and Writing
539664.description: Philosophical concepts, distinctions and methods are used to teach philosophical and argumentative writing that is clear, critical, expressive and precise. Designed to satisfy the classroom portion of the upper-division writing requirement for philosophy majors.

539665.title: Research Ethics
539665.description: Ethical principles and problems implicit in the conduct of scientific research, with special attention to issues of scientific integrity, fraud, deception, data accuracy, authorship credit and use of research funds, especially when animal or human subjects are used.

540925.title: Contemporary Moral Issues
540925.description: Applying ethical and social/political theories to contemporary moral problems. Topics selected from current issues in law, business, medicine, sexual morality, and gender/multicultural studies, including abortion, racism, crime, punishment, welfare, domestic violence and pornography.

539666.title: Existentialism
539666.description: Introduction to existentialist perspectives on freedom, meaning, responsibility, authenticity and self-deception. Typically includes discussion of Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Heidegger and Sartre.

539668.title: Philosophy of Sex and Love
539668.description: Philosophical approaches to love, friendship, marriage and eroticism. Nature of love, relationship between sexuality and love, gender roles and gender equality. Investigates ethical and legal controversies in sexuality, marriage and privacy.

539669.title: Evolution and Creation
539669.description: Interdisciplinary study of evolutionary biology’s impact on culture in context of religious doctrines of creation. Evolutionary theory and religious and philosophical reactions from Darwin to the present, including relevant educational and legal contexts. (PHIL 333 and LBST 333 are the same course.)

539670.title: Philosophy of Feminism
539670.description: Philosophical speculations on how the difference of gender and sex is relevant to every area of human life. What does it mean to be a woman, to be the gender and embodiment of female?  What do women know? (PHIL 343 and WGST 343 are the same course.)

539671.title: Social and Political Philosophy
539671.description: Individualism, community, freedom, authority, justice, human rights and alienation, from the perspective of social and political theory.

539672.title: Philosophy, Literature and Cinema
539672.description: Aesthetics of literature and film, emphasizing how storytelling deepens our imagination and understanding of identity, culture, society and values through use of word and image.

539673.title: Asian Philosophy
539673.description: Asian philosophies such as Taoism, Confucianism and Buddhism (especially Zen): world views, conceptions of human nature and the good life. Applications to martial and non-martial arts. Comparisons with Western philosophies, religions and values.

539674.title: Philosophy and Law in America
539674.description: Moral issues in American law, including free speech, affirmative action and punishment. Influence of politics on legal reasoning and the Constitution. Tension between legal reasoning and equal treatment under the law, and how philosophical theories of law respond to this.

539675.title: First Course in Symbolic Logic
539675.description: Recognition and construction of correct deductions in the sentential logic and the first-order predicate calculus.

539676.title: Meaning and Mind
539676.description: Philosophical issues about language and mind, including topics such as meaning, reference, truth, speech act and belief. (PHIL 375 and LING 375 are the same course).

539677.title: Philosophical Approaches to Race, Class, and Gender
539677.description: Despite the history of analyzing race, class, and gender as separate phenomena, the three are integrally connected. Focus on the interstitial connections among the three to gain knowledge of the formation of race, class and gender.

539678.title: American Philosophy
539678.description: Examines and critiques significant philosophical themes, texts, and trends in the philosophy of the Americas in the late 19th and early 20th century, especially the classical pragmatists (e.g. Peirce, James, Dewey, Addams, DuBois), and their contemporary interpreters (e.g. Misak, Haack, Talisse).

539679.title: Analytic Philosophy
539679.description: Rise and development of the analytic movement in 20th-century philosophy. Study works of such philosophers as Moore, Russell, Wittgenstein and Carnap, Quine, Putnam, and Davidson.

539680.title: Marx and Marxism
539680.description: Marx and his followers in philosophical perspective. Theories of human nature, society and intellectual activity; conceptual tools for the analysis of social phenomena; sources; and followers, both critical and dogmatic.

539681.title: Postmodernism
539681.description: Such modern and post-modern movements as phenomenology, hermeneutics, critical theory, post-structuralism, deconstruction, the Frankfurt school and French feminism; influences of these movements on political, literary and psychoanalytic theory.

539682.title: Directed Study
539682.description: Supervised individual study as an elective. May be repeated with different content for a maximum of 6 units. No more than 3 units may be taken with any one adviser in any one semester. Requires approval of department.

539683.title: Ethical Theory
539683.description: Major ethical theories as advanced by such authors as Aristotle, Kant, Mill and Rawls.

539684.title: Metaphysics
539684.description: Metaphysics and metaphysical issues such as reality, universals, space, time, substance, identity and difference, causality, permanence and change, freedom and determinism, minds and bodies.

539685.title: Phenomenology
539685.description: Ephemeral structure of experience and subjectivity. Conceptualizations of the subject, consciousness, embodiment and engagement with the world. Primary figures include Edmund Husserl, Martin Heidegger and Maurice Merleau-Ponty.

539686.title: Epistemology
539686.description: Nature of knowledge, belief, certainty, truth, perception, and the a priori; examinations of skepticism, traditional responses to skepticism and the foundations of knowledge.

539687.title: Philosophy of Language
539687.description: Key problems in the philosophy of language such as the nature of language, function of language in communication, meaning and reference of proper names, and the connection between thought and language. Not available for graduate degree credit.

539688.title: Philosophy of Mind
539688.description: Contemporary philosophical approaches to the nature of mind. Topics include: artificial intelligence, the relation between the mind and the brain, the nature of consciousness, the possibility of neuroscience providing a complete explanation of experience from the first-person point of view.

539689.title: Seminar in Values
539689.description: Valuation or some important form of value: ethical, aesthetic, political. May be repeated once with different content.

539691.title: Seminar in the History of Philosophy
539691.description: Covers some important work, figure, school or problem in the history of philosophy before 1900. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

539692.title: Seminar in Contemporary Philosophy
539692.description: Issues raised by such 20th-century philosophers as Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Austin, Quine, Husserl, Heidegger, Merleau-Ponty or Foucault.

539693.title: Senior Internship in Ethics and Society
539693.description: Supervised internship in professional setting. Required course project on philosophical and ethical issues. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

539694.title: Independent Study
539694.description: Develop competency in research. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. No more than 3 units may be taken with any one adviser in any one semester.

539696.title: Survey of Physics
539696.description: Basic concepts of physics for the non-science major. Physical concepts in real-world contexts such as global warming. How our ideas about motion, energy, heat and temperature, light and color, electricity, and atoms form a framework for understanding the natural world.

539697.title: Survey of Physics Laboratory
539697.description: Experiments that demonstrate important concepts in astronomy and physics. For non-science majors.

539698.title: Physical Science for Future Elementary Teachers
539698.description: Designed especially for the prospective elementary teacher, this activity-based course examines physical science concepts in real-world contexts such as global warming, kitchen science and the automobile. Lecture and laboratory is combined into a single unified learning experience. (PHYS 102 and  CHEM 102 are the same course.)

545572.title: Quantum Computing for Everyone
545572.description: Introduction to the new field of quantum computing. What is quantum physics?  What is entanglement? What makes a quantum computer so special? Preparation for reading and understanding popular science articles on advances in quantum computing and other quantum technologies.

539699.title: Elementary Physics
539699.description: Introduction to mechanics and thermodynamics. Designed for life and health science majors.

539700.title: Elementary Physics: Laboratory
539700.description: Laboratory for PHYS 211. (3 hours laboratory). Instructional fee required.

539701.title: Elementary Physics
539701.description: Introduction to electricity and magnetism, wave motion and optics. Designed for life and health science majors.

539702.title: Elementary Physics: Laboratory
539702.description: Laboratory for PHYS 212. Instructional fee required. (3 hours laboratory).

539703.title: Fundamental Physics: Mechanics
539703.description: Classical Newtonian mechanics; linear and circular motion; energy; linear/angular momentum; systems of particles; rigid body motion; wave motion and sound.

539704.title: Fundamental Physics: Laboratory
539704.description: Laboratory for PHYS 225. Instructional fee required. (3 hours laboratory)

539705.title: Fundamental Physics: Electricity and Magnetism
539705.description: Electrostatics, electric potential, capacitance, dielectrics, electrical circuits, resistance, emf, electromagnetic induction, magnetism and magnetic materials, and introduction to Maxwell’s equations.

539706.title: Fundamental Physics: Laboratory
539706.description: Laboratory for PHYS 226. Instructional fee required. (3 hours laboratory)

539707.title: Fundamental Physics: Waves, Optics, and Modern Physics
539707.description: Geometrical and physical optics, wave phenomena; quantum physics, including the photoelectric effect, line spectra and the Bohr atom; the wave nature of matter, Schroedinger’s equation and solutions; the Uncertainty Principle, special theory of relativity.

539708.title: Fundamental Physics: Laboratory
539708.description: Laboratory for PHYS 227. Instructional fee required. (3 hours laboratory)

539709.title: Survey of Mathematical Physics
539709.description: Mathematical techniques required for upper-division physics courses, including differential vector operators, complex variables, partial and ordinary differential equations, special functions, Fourier transforms and series, matrices and operators, probability and statistics.

539710.title: Energy and Sustainability
539710.description: Basic physical principles applied to the generation and use of energy. Conventional and alternative energy sources. Environmental consequences of energy use, greenhouse effect, global warming. Energy conservation principles.

541198.title: Physics of Sound
541198.description: Applying physical principles in music, including topics such as sound wave propagation, time periodicity, vibrations, resonance, acoustics and human perception. Selected topics in stringed, woodwind, brass instruments, the human voice, recording and playback, and digital vs. analog music.

539711.title: Thermodynamics, Kinetic Theory, and Statistical Physics
539711.description: Laws of thermodynamics with physical, chemical and engineering applications; kinetic theory of gases. Introduction to statistical physics with reexamination of laws of thermodynamics.

539712.title: Computational Physics
539712.description: Previous computing experience recommended. Basic numerical methods in physics. Applications include curve fitting and minimization, numerical simulation of classical particles, waves and Fourier analysis, quantum square well, Monte Carlo methods and diffusion. Hands-on computing with high-level languages, graphics and symbolic mathematics. (1 hour lecture, 4 hours activity)

539713.title: Classical Mechanics
539713.description: Classical mechanics and associated mathematical and numerical techniques: Newtonian dynamics; Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics.

538522.title: Introduction to Geology
538522.description: Introduction to the science of rocks, fossils, volcanoes, earthquakes, landscapes and oceans. Natural hazards, geology in everyday life and geology as field of practice. High school algebra recommended.

538523.title: Introduction to Geology Laboratory
538523.description: Hands-on analysis and evaluation of rocks, maps, geologic time and Earth processes. Natural hazards, geology in everyday life and scientific inquiry.

538524.title: Earth Science Investigations for Future Teachers
538524.description: For prospective elementary school teachers. A laboratory and activity-based introduction to the field of earth science: fundamental Earth; atmospheric, oceanic and astronomical science concepts; potential impacts of natural hazards on planet Earth.

538525.title: Topics in Earth Science
538525.description: Public interest topics in Earth science. Alternating topics include dinosaur world, earthquakes and volcanoes. Courses may include integrated labs, lectures and field trips that explore mainstream Earth science issues. (3 hours lecture, field trips.)

538526.title: Earth History
538526.description: Evolution of Earth as interpreted from rocks, fossils and geologic structures. Plate tectonics provides a unifying theme for consideration of mountain building, evolution of life and ancient environments. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

538527.title: Earth History Supplemental Lab
538527.description: Supervised research on topics related to Earth history. Project will result in a term paper and/or web page. (3 hours laboratory, field trips)

540308.title: Directed Field and Laboratory Study
540308.description: Research under the supervision of a geology faculty member. Intended for students who may not have completed sufficient coursework to allow them to work independently, but who are eager for research experience. May be repeated for university credit.

538528.title: Earth Materials
538528.description: Identifying rock-forming minerals based on their chemical, physical and optical properties; relating mineral identification to rock lithology and classification; interpreting the significance of a rock’s mineral assemblage in terms of its igneous, metamorphic, sedimentary or hydrothermal origin. (1 hour discussion,2 hours activity, 6 hours laboratory, field trips.)

538529.title: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
538529.description: Description, classification, occurrence and origin of igneous and metamorphic rocks. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory, field trips)

538530.title: Topics in California-Related Geology
538530.description: Directed investigations of one aspect of Earth science. Alternating topics include geology of California, earthquakes, geologic hazards of California, geology of national parks, Earth’s environmental crisis and California’s water crisis. May be repeated for credit with a different topic. Some topics offered for 3 units only. (3 hours lecture for 5, 10, or 15 weeks; optional field trip)

538531.title: Sedimentation and Stratigraphy
538531.description: Sedimentary rocks, including: classification, texture, mineralogy and provenance; introduction to sedimentary environments and interpretation of ancient environments in the rock record; study of stratigraphic methods and patterns. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory, field trips)

538532.title: Paleontology
538532.description: Identification, systematics, evolution, ichnology, biostratigraphy, taphonomy and paleoecologic analysis of fossil groups. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips).

538533.title: General Oceanography
538533.description: Chemical, physical and geological nature of the oceans. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

538534.title: Hydrology and Surface Processes
538534.description: The impact of surface water on the formation of soils, weathering, surface features (rivers) and groundwater. Applying hydrology as a predictive and postdictive tool on geologic, biotic and engineering problems.

540723.title: GEO/BIO Field Investigations
540723.description: Develop field-based skills used to observe landforms, infer geological processes and identify impacts on biotic properties. Apply knowledge to an inquiry-based challenge problem. Includes a mandatory six- to 10-day field trip plus expenses. (GEOL 336 and BIOL 336 are the same course.)

538535.title: Earth’s Interior
538535.description: Geophysical, geochemical properties of mantle and core. Data collection techniques. Impact of internal processes on crustal/surface phenomena.

538536.title: Structural Geology
538536.description: Faults, folds, mechanics of rock deformation and elementary tectonics; solution of problems by geometric, trigonometric and stereographic analysis. (1 hour lecture discussion, 2 hours activity, 6 hours laboratory, field trips)

538537.title: Geologic Field Techniques
538537.description: Basic geologic field equipment. In-class and weekend field projects include: basic geologic mapping on topographic maps and aerial photographs; field note-taking methods; field data interpretation; preparing geologic maps; preparing stratigraphic columns and geologic cross-sections; technical report writing. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours in-field activity, weekend field trips)

540663.title: Data Collection and Analysis For Earth Scientists
540663.description: This course will introduce students to different data types typical in earth/environmental science applications, and how to plan, collect, analyze, interpret, and report on such data to answer a scientific question.

538538.title: Optical Mineralogy and Petrography
538538.description: Principles of optical mineralogy and use of petrographic microscope to analyze minerals and textures of igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks. (1 hour lecture, 6 hours laboratory, field trip)

538539.title: Geochemistry
538539.description: Basic chemical and thermodynamic principles applied to the origin and alteration of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks and economic mineral deposits.

538540.title: Volcanology
538540.description: Volcanic eruptions and their deposits, hazards and impact on society. Classroom activities and field trips (required) will explore modern and ancient volcanic environments. (1 hour lecture discussion, 3 hours laboratory, field trips).

538541.title: Planet Earth for Educators
538541.description: Project-based course to prepare for teaching Earth Science in K-8 or credential program. Earth Science concepts, the Next Generation Science Standards, and how to teach using them. Develop lesson plans and activities, and practice teaching with peers. Not available for graduate degree credit in M.S. Geology; available for graduate credit in education program. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity)

540869.title: Earth Science Communication, Education and Outreach Methods
540869.description: Pedagogical and communication techniques for K-14 and public informal education within the contextual constructs of Earth Science. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

541160.title: Coastal Processes
541160.description: How marine and terrestrial processes combine to influence coastal environments. How these processes are reflected in the resulting stratigraphy and morphology, how they impact humans, and how humans impact these processes.

538542.title: Hydrogeology
538542.description: Occurrence, movement and utilization of groundwater resources; geological, geophysical and hydrological methods for groundwater exploration and development. Well hydraulics and ground-water contamination. (1 hour lecture discussion, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

538543.title: Paleoclimatology
538543.description: Methods and archives used to understand past climate; examining atmospheric circulation, oceanic circulation and the Earth’s energy budget in the context of past climate change. (1 hour lecture discussion, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

538544.title: Geophysics
538544.description: Seismic refraction, gravity, magnetic and electrical techniques and fundamentals as applied to determine subsurface structure, groundwater and location of mineral resources. (1 hour lecture discussion, 3 hours laboratory, field trips). PHYS 226 or PHYS 212 recommended.

538545.title: Environmental Geology
538545.description: Geologic processes, hazards, mineral and energy resources and their interaction with planning and environmental regulations. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours lab, field trips)

538546.title: Quaternary Tectonics
538546.description: Processes and products of relatively young Quaternary tectonics. Evaluating surface tectonic features, their ages, deformation styles and structural regimes. Assessment of past and contemporary deformation rates. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory, field trips)

540293.title: Engineering Geology
540293.description: Geology applied to engineering works. Earth materials, processes; site evaluation techniques; geologic hazard analysis; case histories. (1 hour lecture, 3 hours laboratory, field trips)

538547.title: Geology Field Camp I
538547.description: Advanced geologic mapping in a variety of geologic settings. Requires field report, map and cross-sections. Instructional fee required. (45 hours per week for four weeks during summer)

538548.title: Directed Studies
538548.description: Directed studies in specialized areas of the geological sciences, such as petroleum geology, sedimentology, optical and instrumentation techniques. Library research and written reports required. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 units. Not available for M.S. Geology graduate credit.

538549.title: Geological Sciences Internship
538549.description: Geological sciences work experience, salaried or volunteer, with industry, government or private agencies. Student intern will be supervised by faculty adviser and employer. (1 hour of seminar per week plus a total of 120-150 hours of work experience)

538550.title: Geological Sciences Tutorial
538550.description: Provides a maximum of 6 hours per week of supervised tutoring or teaching experiences (including office hours) for undergraduate students assisting in laboratory or field geology classes.  Not available for M.S. geology graduate credit.

538551.title: Undergraduate Thesis
538551.description: Extension of an advanced course, conducted independently by the student under faculty supervision, culminating in a paper of professional quality. Must be taken for credit for a maximum of three units. Requires approval of thesis adviser for first unit. Completion of thesis proposal that is approved by thesis adviser and the Department Undergraduate Adviser for second and subsequent units.

538552.title: Independent Study
538552.description: Independent study of a topic selected in consultation with and completed under the supervision of the instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Not available for M.S. geology degree credit.

538553.title: Advanced Geological Concepts and Methods
538553.description: Current advances in geological concepts emphasizing Southern California geology. Develop tools to construct a thesis proposal: research planning; developing thesis topics; bibliographic methods; research design (laboratory and field); research proposal preparation. May include seminars, group projects and field trips. (2 hours lecture, 2 hours activity, field trips)

538554.title: Advanced Topics in Geochemistry
538554.description: Special topics on modern techniques and recent advances in geochemistry, such as geochronology and environmental isotope geochemistry. May be repeated once for credit with different topic. (3 hours lecture; field trips)

538555.title: Advanced Topics in Geology
538555.description: Modern techniques and recent advances in geology such as basin analysis, carbonate sedimentology, paleontology, paleolimnology, igneous petrology, tectonics and studies of the Mesozoic Era. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 12 units. (2 hours discussion; 3 hours field laboratory; field trips)

538556.title: Advanced Topics in Hydrogeology
538556.description: Modern techniques and recent advances in hydrogeology, such as groundwater modeling, well hydraulics and aquifer analysis, contaminant hydrogeology, hydrogeochemistry and environmental sampling and protocols. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 12 units. (2 hours discussion; 3 hours field laboratory; field trips)

538557.title: Advanced Topics in Engineering Geology
538557.description: Modern techniques and recent advances in engineering geology, such as Quaternary geology, landslide analysis and paleoseismology. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 9 units. (2 hours discussion; 3 hours field laboratory; field trips)

538558.title: Geoscience Seminar
538558.description: Attendance at departmental and other seminars. Discussion and/or written assignments based on seminar topics required. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.

538559.title: Directed Graduate Studies in the Geosciences
538559.description: Directed studies of specialized geoscience topics not covered by existing courses and tailored to individual student interest. Literature research, recitations and written reports required. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.

538560.title: Thesis
538560.description: Completion of M.S. Thesis proposal that is approved by the thesis committee and the Department Graduate Committee Chair for second and subsequent units. Design, analyze and present a research problem culminating in a thesis for the master’s degree. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires approval of thesis adviser for the first unit.

538561.title: Independent Graduate Research
538561.description: Independent research on an approved topic. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Requires approval of adviser and Department Graduate Committee.

539279.title: Fundamental German-A
539279.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Introduction to customs and culture of German-speaking countries. Conducted primarily in German.

539280.title: Fundamental German-B
539280.description: Continued development of listening and reading comprehension, speaking, writing and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Further study of customs and culture of German-speaking countries. Conducted primarily in German.

539281.title: Intermediate German-A
539281.description: Develop listening comprehension and speaking. Vocabulary building and developing conversational skills. Conducted in German. May be taken concurrently with GRMN 204 or GRMN 214.

539282.title: Intermediate German-B
539282.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension and writing. Vocabulary building and developing writing competency. Conducted in German. May be taken concurrently with GRMN 203 or GRMN 214.

539284.title: Directed Study
539284.description: Supervised study projects in the German language. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

539294.title: Advanced Writing and Speaking
539294.description: Practice writing on various topics in detail, expressing hypotheses and presenting arguments or points of view accurately and effectively. Development differences of formal and informal style. Conducted in German.

539295.title: Independent Study
539295.description: Supervised research projects in German language or literature to be taken only with consent of instructor and department chair. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

538611.title: World Civilizations to the 16th Century
538611.description: Development of Western and non-Western civilizations from their origins to the 16th century.

538612.title: World Civilizations Since the 16th Century
538612.description: Development of Western and non-Western civilizations from the 16th century to the present.

541221.title: Imagining Technology in History
541221.description: How human cultures historically have imagined and represented technology in literature, philosophy, religion and the arts. Examine, through case studies from world history, how diverse cultures have grappled with the impact of technology on human existence.

541331.title: Explore Core: Teens in Trouble
541331.description: Teens in trouble through multiple lenses. The physiological and environmental conditions that impact adolescents. How societies interpret and react to teens in trouble. Apply holistic knowledge to developing personal and/or economic well-being and promoting societal responsibilities to youth. (CAS 130, BIOL 130, BUAD 130, and HIST 130 are the same course)

538613.title: United States to 1877
538613.description: Political, social, economic and cultural development of the United States to 1877. Old World background, rise of the new nation, sectional problems, the Civil War and Reconstruction.

538614.title: United States Since 1877
538614.description: U.S. history from the late 19th century to the present. Economic transformation, political reform movements, social, cultural and intellectual changes and the role of the United States in world affairs.

538615.title: Survey of American History
538615.description: American history from prehistoric times (before 1492) to the present according to chronological time periods. Basic themes that pervade the entire sweep of the nation’s history. Satisfies state requirement in U.S. History.

538616.title: Survey of American History with Emphasis on Ethnic Minorities
538616.description: Survey of American history from prehistoric times (before 1492) to the present with special emphasis on the role of race and ethnicity. (HIST 190, AFAM 190, ASAM 190 and CHIC 190 are the same course.)

541222.title: Ideas, Books, And Beliefs: Texts that Changed History
541222.description: Probes a central historical question: how ideas change, by examining the role of fictional and non-fiction texts in fundamentally altering a people’s belief systems.

540879.title: The History of Asian Pacific Americans
540879.description: Origins and evolution of Asian American communities and cultures, with an emphasis upon the southern California region, through selected books, oral histories, films, outside speakers and excursions. (HIST 201 and ASAM 201 are the same course.)

541264.title: Discovering My Roots: Genealogy, Family, History
541264.description: The meanings and forms of family in world history by engaging the methods and practices of history research: theoretical literature, genealogy databases, oral histories, personal digital archives, family history rooms. Produce substantive research on own families. (HIST 202 and AGNG 202 are the same course).

541223.title: Baseball History
541223.description: Examines history of baseball through art, films, memoirs, music and fiction. In playing, watching, writing about and contemplating the nation’s most creative, complicated and exported sport, diverse Americans have defined themselves and their connections to other regions of the world.

541265.title: How to be a Leader, Ancient Greek Style
541265.description: Introduces major approaches to the subject of leadership in ancient Greece through ancient poetry, history, philosophy, and biography. Discuss and analyze ancient texts to enable students to develop their own answers to the challenges of contemporary leadership.

541224.title: Clashing Steel: Classic and Medieval War and Society
541224.description: History of the global emergence and experience of organized violence, evolution of strategy and tactics, the impact of technology on warfare, and the relationship between military and civilians in pre-modern eras. Topically examines social and cultural reactions to war.

541225.title: Roar of Cannons: Modern War and Society
541225.description: Developments following the introduction of gunpowder. The evolution of military strategy and tactics, impact of technology on warfare, and relationship between war and civilian populations.

538617.title: Historical Thinking
538617.description: Nature of history, history of historical thought and history’s relationship to the humanities and social sciences. Seminar required of all history majors. History majors must earn at a “C” (2.0) or better.

538618.title: Historical Writing
538618.description: Research, writing and library usage (including computer-assisted bibliographic searches) as related to history. Meets the classroom portion of the upper-division writing requirement for history majors. Seminar required of all history majors. History majors must earn at least a “C” (2.0) in this course.

541226.title: History, Film and Trouble
541226.description: Historical films can be dangerous, and many governments try to censor or ban them. Discusses historical films that deal with trouble: periods and actions in the past that bring embarrassment and shame in the present.

574328.title: Jazz and Modernity
574328.description: Jazz in 20th-century history and politics; its interaction with literature, film, the visual arts and dance in the context of aesthetic and philosophical movements and concepts of race and gender.

538619.title: The California Experience
538619.description: Seven themes in California studies. Explores the California experience through readings, films and music, and three writing assignments that ask them to research one topic each in the arts/humanities, social sciences and natural sciences in California. (LBST 310 and HIST 310 are the same course.)

538620.title: World War II
538620.description: History of World War II: Films, documentaries, lectures and discussion.

541266.title: Imagining Alexander the Great
541266.description: Ways in which the historical figure of Alexander the Great has been represented and interpreted by writers and artists for over two millennia in the cultures of Europe, the Middle East, North Africa and South Asia.

541227.title: Travels in Time
541227.description: The encounters of travelers with people and places around the world through time. Locations and time periods will vary.

538621.title: A European Tour
538621.description: Interdisciplinary introduction to the development of European civilization in the pre-modern period through an examination of select sites. The geographical and environmental context, the peopling of Europe and the evolution of cultural, political, economic and religious ideas and institutions. (HIST 315 and LBST 315 are the same course.)

538622.title: Modern European History 1789 - Present
538622.description: Major political, social, economic and cultural developments in Modern Europe: French Revolution, industrial revolution, liberalism, socialism, nationalism, imperialism, urbanization, modernity, the World Wars, Russian Revolution, inter-war period and post-1945 period.

541228.title: Cross-Cultural History of Medicine
541228.description: The diversity of health and healing systems from the early modern period to the present. Employ an interdisciplinary approach to examine the science and ethics of health and healing across a variety of geographical, historical and cultural contexts. (LBST 325 and HIST 325 are the same course.)

538645.title: Magic, Mysticism and Witchcraft in Early Modern Europe
538645.description: Magical thinking in Europe from its medieval roots through the 17th century. The currents of magical thinking in elite and popular culture and its manifestations in Renaissance science and philosophy and in the witch craze.

541164.title: History of Early Science and Technology
541164.description: Science and technology in the development of human culture, especially the interactions among science, technology and society in ancient Greece and China, medieval and Renaissance Europe, and Islam. (HIST 330 and

538623.title: History of Science: Copernicus to the Present
538623.description: Science from the 16th century to the present, especially the scientific revolutions of the 17th and 20th centuries and the interaction between science, technology and culture. (HIST 331 and LBST 331 are the same course.)

538624.title: Concepts and Approaches in Women’s History
538624.description: Overview of problems, concepts, methodologies and debates that have characterized women’s history in recent decades. (HIST 332 and WGST 332 are the same course.)

541229.title: Big History
541229.description: History of the universe, from the Big Bang to the present, examining ways in which discoveries from the sciences give fresh insights into the origins and importance of humanity and the modern world.

541230.title: Americans in Italy
541230.description: The encounters of traveling Americans-writers, visual artists, collectors, soldiers and filmmakers-with Italy from the late colonial to post-World War II eras.

541023.title: Ancient Eats: Food and Foodways in the Ancient World
541023.description: Food in the Roman Empire and elsewhere in the ancient world. Farming, sustainability, trade, purchasing, processing, production, ingredients, terroir, recipes, tools, the place and function of feasts, and food in myth, cult and philosophy (LBST 341 and HIST 341 are the same course.)

540881.title: History of Latin American Civilization
540881.description: Social, economic, political and cultural evolution of Latin America from the European conquest to the present.

538625.title: History of African Civilization
538625.description: Social, political, economic and cultural evolution of African civilizations from early times to the present.

538626.title: Modern Asia: Nationalism and Revolutionary Change
538626.description: Modular analysis of nationalism, revolution and modernization as drawn from the experiences of countries in Asia, including China, Japan, Korea, India, Vietnam, Indonesia and the Philippines.

541231.title: The Great Depression
541231.description: Political and cultural responses to the Great Depression of the 1930s through speeches, oral histories, literature, music and the visual arts.

538627.title: Women’s Image in American Film
538627.description: Images, symbols, visual metaphors and myths as they relate to the image of women. Change in film images will be contrasted with the changing status of women in America. Not available for graduate degree credit.

538692.title: American Legal and Constitutional History
538692.description: Legal and constitutional issues affecting the development of the U.S. Constitution, American law and government. Developments from English and colonial legal origins to constitutional problems of the post-World War II era.

538693.title: American Military History
538693.description: America’s military experience focusing upon the democratic, industrial, managerial, mechanical, scientific and social revolutions that have molded military institutions and national policies.

538628.title: World War II Japanese American Evacuation
538628.description: World War II eviction and detention of people of Japanese ancestry in the United States, pivoting on the significance of this experience in the areas of civil and human rights, cross-cultural relations and international affairs. Not available for graduate degree credit. (HIST 382 and ASAM 382 are the same course.)

540882.title: American Social History 1750-1860
540882.description: Social history of the United States to the Civil War. How different groups shaped American history and respond to changing laws, institutions and economic realities. Theories and methods social historians use.

540883.title: American Social History 1865-1930
540883.description: Social history of the United States from the Civil War; reform, social organization and values. Women’s movement, censorship, divorce, the child and the limits of reform movements in an organizational society.

538629.title: The American Civil War
538629.description: History of the American Civil War. Both contemporary and current analyses of the war will be amplified by the use of films and slides.

538630.title: World War I
538630.description: Explores military, cultural, social, economic, ecological, and political aspects of the war using film, literature and other sources.

538631.title: Concepts in World History, Ancient to Early Modern
538631.description: For students intending to teach world history. Ways in which world history can be conceptualized. Nomadism, syncretism, cross-cultural trade and European diffusionism.

540624.title: Concepts in World History
540624.description: Designed primarily for students intending to teach world history. Introduction to various conceptual approaches to world history and the major themes of modern world history, including industrialization, imperialism, nationalism and globalization.

539958.title: Introduction to Sociology
539958.description: Basic concepts of sociology: social interaction, culture, personality, social processes, population, social class, the community, social institutions and socio-cultural change.

539959.title: Introduction to Aging Studies
539959.description: Multidisciplinary overview of: characteristics, strengths and problems of older persons; diversity in aging process involving gender, race, ethnicity, subculture; services to older adults; gerontology as an academic discipline and a field of practice. (AGNG 133, SOCI 133, PUBH 133, HUSR 133 and PSYC 133 are the same course.)

541145.title: Social Media and Social Interaction
541145.description: Self, identities, culture, communities, inequalities and social interaction as experienced through social media and technology. Use sociological perspectives to evaluate the benefits and hazards of social media for self and society.

539960.title: Social Work
539960.description: History, philosophy, values of social work profession, fields of practice (casework, group work, macro practice); theories of human behavior in social environments. Social work as career objective and qualifications necessary. Recommended for students considering careers in human services, social work, social policy development.

539961.title: Social Research Methods
539961.description: Qualitative and quantitative perspectives on social research. Purpose and components of qualitative and quantitative research design, including the role of theory in research, sampling, reflexivity, the practice of mixed methods of data collection, analysis and writing results.

539962.title: Statistics for the Social Sciences
539962.description: Techniques for the elementary statistical analysis of social data. Description and inferential measures include tests, chi-square, analysis of variance, contingency table analysis and linear regression.

539963.title: Black Families in America
539963.description: Issues of race, class, gender, sexuality and identity within African American families. Topics will include: black single mothers and welfare, prisons, black middle class families and residential housing, black youth and activism, and LGBT family formations. (AFAM 304 and SOCI 304 are the same course.)

539964.title: Social Work Practice
539964.description: Theories, methods, principles, ethics, fields of social work practice. Generalist model; micro (individual), mezzo (group), macro (organization, community, advocacy, case management) levels of intervention. Methods and theories underlying social work practice. Recommended for students considering careers in human services, counseling, social work or social policy development.

539965.title: Applying Sociology in the Community
539965.description: Combines community service with an analysis of select community issues. At least 40 hours of community service required, applying theories and methods to field site. Findings and analysis discussed in weekly meetings.

540657.title: Sociology for Career Success
540657.description: Examines key sociological theories and concepts to situate work in the context of historical, hierarchical power relations that reproduce dominance. Uses sociology to help navigate job markets, career opportunities, and improve mobility in post-industrial world of work.

539966.title: Writing for Sociology Students
539966.description: Composition, sources of information and sociological writing for different audiences. Satisfies the classroom portion of the upper-division writing requirement for sociology majors. Instructional fee.

539967.title: The American Drug Scene
539967.description: Uses sociological research and theory to understand drug use in the U.S. Drug subcultures, moral panics, the social consequences of drug policies, crime and trends in drug use.

539968.title: Social Interaction
539968.description: Social and socio-psychological dimensions of group behavior and the socialization of the individual. Social interaction and its impact on the individual and personality formation.

539969.title: Sociology of Communication
539969.description: Social processes involved in communicating with symbols-verbal, visual and “body-language” - in interpersonal settings and the mass media.

539970.title: Social Movements
539970.description: Characteristics and analysis of social movements and collective behavior. Major theoretical approaches, review past and present collective actions, and assess the efficacy and potentiality of producing social, cultural and political change.

539971.title: Social Relationships and Emotions
539971.description: Consideration of social relationships emphasizing emotional bonds as the primary integrating force, including interactions between emotions and relationships.

539972.title: Sociology of Families
539972.description: The family as a social institution. Historical and cross-cultural perspectives; social change affecting marriage and the family; analysis of American courtship and marriage patterns; the psycho-dynamics of family life.

539973.title: The Sociology of Education
539973.description: Education as a social institution and agent of socialization. Dynamic interplay with economic, political, religious, family institutions, and community. Gender, race, and class inequality in education. Cross-national perspectives on education and related social problems and social policy.

539974.title: Sociology of Children and Youth
539974.description: Historical, cross-national, and contemporary views of children, adolescents and youth in society; childhood socialization and the effects of the family, school, peers, gender roles, the media community, and technology; social problems of children and youth; recommendations for social policy.

539975.title: Gender, Sex and Society
539975.description: Gender as a social and institutional construct, including analyses of identity, sexuality, media, family, work, economy, the state, and global relations.

539976.title: Women in Contemporary Societies
539976.description: Micro and macro analyses of women’s roles and experiences in contemporary societies. Topics may include gender socialization, institutional inequalities, women’s work, violence against women, resistant to inequality, women’s health and sexuality.

539977.title: Social Inequality
539977.description: Development, patterns, structures and consequences of social inequality, with emphasis on social class, race, ethnicity, gender, and sexuality in the U.S. Dynamics of resistance and social change are also discussed.

539978.title: Race and Ethnic Relations
539978.description: Development and current conditions of minority/majority relations through study of social, political and economic causes and consequences of prejudice and discrimination. Evolutionary and revolutionary movements for change will be studied.

539979.title: Sociology of Death and Dying
539979.description: Dying as a social process; functions of bereavement behavior; the grief process; fear of death and dying; death related rituals, demographic aspects of mortality; American death acceptance-denial controversy.

539980.title: Population and the Environment
539980.description: Population composition, growth and movement. Social factors affecting birth rates, death rates and migration. Environmental and resource base implications of population growth, urbanization and migration. Role of the economy, poverty, gender and development on population dynamics.

539981.title: Law and Society
539981.description: Relationship between a society and its laws using sociological theory and major concepts. Analyze court process, legal professions, and related social institutions.

540230.title: Deviant Behavior
540230.description: Social construction, nature and patterns of deviance. Topics include theories of deviance, research on deviance, types of deviance, constructing deviance, deviant identity, relations among deviants, deviant acts, and deviant careers.

539982.title: Sociology of City Life
539982.description: Ecology, patterns of growth, institutional inequalities, social problems, cultures, and organized resistances of urban communities in global contexts.

541146.title: The Social Life of Food
541146.description: “Food” has a social reality, created out of institutions and global systems. Investigate this reality through food’s production, distribution and consumption within a globalized and commoditized modern world. Inequalities and social struggle, including food justice movements.

539983.title: Sociology of Human Sexuality
539983.description: Sociological aspects of sexualities, socio-historical and comparative perspectives; relationships of sexual constructs to life cycle, gender, race, class, nation and power.

539984.title: Family Violence
539984.description: Contemporary issues of family violence: victims, perpetrators and societal responses. Explores causes, intervention and prevention of all types of abuse - child, sibling, spouse, parent and elder - through the examination of theories, research findings and practical field application.

539985.title: Sexual Abuse in American Society
539985.description: Sociological examination of sexual abuse in contemporary society, specifically patterns of forcible rape and child sexual victimization. Theories and research findings regarding causes, consequences and other dynamics of sexual victimization, including responses of social groups to such victimization.

539986.title: Theories of Social Behavior
539986.description: Main schools of sociological thought, both European and American. Systems of theory, methodology of theorists, cultural change and social institutions.

539987.title: Criminology
539987.description: Extent, causes and control of criminal behavior. Criminal law, causal factors and theories, correctional institutions, probation and parole and preventive efforts.

539988.title: Juvenile Delinquency
539988.description: Juvenile delinquency as a social problem. Sociological study of the causes of delinquent behavior and programs of control, treatment and prevention.

539989.title: Mass Incarceration and Punishment
539989.description: Histories, theories, policies and practices thathave influenced the development of the U.S. correctional system. Topics may include background and social contexts associated with incarceration, correctional institutions, inmate populations and subcultures,and prison administration/management.

540645.title: Violence against Women and Girls: Global Realities
540645.description: Violence against women of all ages in the global context. The ways violence against women manifests and is explained across cultural, sociodemographic and geographic boundaries.

539990.title: Sociology of Aging
539990.description: Population age structure; theories of aging; aging in family, economic, political, religious, educational, leisure/esthetic institutions, aging and ethnicity, social policy and the future of aging.

539991.title: Sociology of Health and Illness
539991.description: Comprehensive sociological perspective for interpreting medicine and medical behavior. Considers disease processes as they affect the individual and others in this environment, health practice and petitioners, health institutions and the cost and service of health services in a multifaceted approach.

540263.title: Immigrant Orange County
540263.description: Migration through the lens of Orange County. Requires research project including data collection (surveys or interviews or focus groups), data analysis and report writing. (SOCI 456 and GEOG 456 are the same course.)

539992.title: Sociology of Religious Behavior
539992.description: Religious behavior examined by social science theories. Religious rituals/beliefs to cope with anxiety and powerlessness before natural forces and social structures and processes. Religion’s contributions to individual identity, societal order and change.

539993.title: Political Sociology
539993.description: Theoretical perspectives; nature of power and authority; social structure and political institutions; elites and decision making; social influences on political behavior; political movements.

539994.title: Sociology of Sport
539994.description: Nature, position, functions and growing importance of sports in contemporary industrial society. Relationships between structure, variety and extent of sports activity and other institutional sectors in society.

541300.title: Sociology of Money
541300.description: Sociological perspectives on history, nature, functioning and impact of economic perspectives and phenomena. Topics include money, markets, prices and value, commodification, the state, networks and inequality.

539995.title: Social Behavior in Organizations
539995.description: Sociological analysis of formal organizations (industrial, governmental, welfare, military, medical, educational, correctional, etc.) as systems of social interaction. Blueprinted vs. informal organization, structure, authority, decision-making, role conflicts, communication and morals.

540262.title: Research Applicatons
540262.description: Design and implement an individual research project that integrates accumulated training from previous courses in a single in-depth exploration of a topic of interest.

539996.title: Sociological Internship
539996.description: Supervised field experience permitting application of relevant sociological material in practical settings. Requires 120 hours in the field. May be repeated once for credit.

539997.title: Independent Study
539997.description: Individual research project, either library or field. Must enroll with an instructor whose recognized interests are in the area of the planned independent study. Conferences with the instructor as necessary; work culminates in one or more papers. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

539998.title: Seminar: Topics in Societal Structure and Process
539998.description: Analyze a specialization within the study of society such as: socialization and personality; deviance; social change; institutional structure and process. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 18 units.

539999.title: The Research Process
539999.description: Requires the completion of a research project including such elements as theory construction, hypotheses formation, sampling, survey construction, data collection and data analysis. Meets the University Graduate Writing Requirement. Instructional fee.

540000.title: The Research Process
540000.description: Problems of social research. Causal inferences, value bias and measurement, construction of scales. Instructional fee.

540002.title: Advanced Theories of Social Behavior
540002.description: Basic elements and key problems in constructing and evaluating sociological theories.

540003.title: The Practice of Sociology
540003.description: The nexus between theory and methods in current sociological research. Uses applied skills to critically analyze specialized studies in sociology.

540004.title: Teaching Symposium
540004.description: Placement with mentor for training to teach college-level sociology classes. pedagogy, course design and assessment. Requires consent of adviser.

540005.title: Project
540005.description: Under the direction of a faculty member: select a topic that integrates learning in the program with an applied area of interest; develop and submit a major project on the topic. May be repeated once for credit. Requires classified standing in the M.A. in Sociology program, and proposal approved by supervising faculty member and the Sociology Department Graduate Studies committee.

540006.title: Thesis
540006.description: Individual research under supervision, reported in a thesis and defended successfully in an oral examination conducted by a faculty committee. Requires acceptance as a candidate for the M.A. in Sociology, and approval of topic.

540007.title: Independent Graduate Research
540007.description: Individual research on a library or empirical project, with conferences with instructor as necessary, culminating in one or more papers. May be repeated once for credit. Requires consent of graduate adviser and instructor.

539335.title: Fundamental Spanish-A
539335.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking, writing and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Introduction to customs, culture and civilization of Spanish-speaking communities. Conducted primarily in Spanish.

539336.title: Fundamental Spanish-B
539336.description: Continued development of listening and reading comprehension, speaking, writing and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Introduction to customs, culture and civilization of Spanish-speaking communities. Conducted primarily in Spanish.

539338.title: Spanish for Spanish Speakers
539338.description: Intermediate course designed to further develop existing communicative skills in Spanish. May not receive credit for both SPAN 202 and SPAN 204. Conducted in Spanish.

539339.title: Intermediate Spanish-A
539339.description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking and writing Spanish based on cultural and literary materials. Oral expression and developing correct pronunciation. Conducted in Spanish. Concurrent enrollment in SPAN 213 recommended.

539340.title: Intermediate Spanish-B
539340.description: Continued development of listening and reading comprehension, practice in speaking and writing Spanish based on cultural and literary materials. Vocabulary building and developing grammatical accuracy. Conducted in Spanish. Concurrent enrollment in SPAN 214 recommended.

539341.title: Intermediate Conversation
539341.description: Practice in oral expression. Not open to students with native-speaking proficiency in Spanish. Conducted in Spanish. Concurrent enrollment in SPAN 203 recommended.

539342.title: Intermediate Composition
539342.description: Practice in written expression based on cultural and literary materials. Conducted in Spanish. Concurrent enrollment in SPAN 204 recommended.

539343.title: Advanced Grammar and Composition
539343.description: Grammar analysis and written expression. Conducted in Spanish.

540255.title: Writing for the Hispanic Media
540255.description: A hands-on writing course designed to provide the foundations of effective copywriting to reach the Hispanic community using diverse media. Conducted primarily in Spanish.

540243.title: Spanish for Health and Human Services - A
540243.description: Provides students in the health professions with an introduction to the skills necessary to effectively communicate in Spanish, using terminology and culturally appropriate expressions specific to the field.

540244.title: Spanish for Health and Human Services - B
540244.description: Provides students in the health professions with skills necessary to effectively communicate in Spanish at an advanced level, using terminology and culturally appropriate expressions specific to the field.

539344.title: Spanish in the Business World
539344.description: Practical vocabulary and structure of business language, as well as the cultural background of business procedures in the Hispanic world. No credit toward Spanish major or minor. Conducted in Spanish.

539345.title: Spanish for International Business
539345.description: Acquire vocabulary appropriate to the Hispanic business world and study its economic institutions. Emphasizes reading comprehension, conversation and composition. No credit toward Spanish major or minor. Conducted in Spanish.

539346.title: Introduction to Spanish Civilization
539346.description: Readings and discussions on Spanish literature, arts, and institutions. Strengthens facility in the language. Conducted in Spanish.

539347.title: Introduction to Spanish-American Civilization
539347.description: Readings and discussion in Spanish-American literature, arts and institutions. Strengthening of facility in the language. Conducted in Spanish.

540245.title: Contemporary Culture of Spain
540245.description: Develop an understanding of the culture of Spain from the beginning of the 20th century to the present day. Ideologies, institutions, literature and arts. Conducted in Spanish.

540246.title: Spanish-American Modern Culture
540246.description: Develop an understanding of Spanish-American culture from the 19th century to the present day. Ideologies, institutions, literature and arts. Conducted in Spanish.

539348.title: Introduction to Literary Forms
539348.description: Introduction to literary forms and concepts of literary techniques and criticism. Analysis and interpretation of various texts. Strengthens abilities in reading, language and literary criticism. Conducted in Spanish.

539349.title: Advanced Writing in Cultural Studies
539349.description: Cultural studies approaches (race, gender and sexuality, social class, social movements, identity and power, etc.) in Hispanic/Latinx contexts. Refining critical and analytical competencies and developing academic writing at an advanced level. Conducted in Spanish.

540500.title: Spanish Editorial Convergence Writing Model
540500.description: Review and analyze new editorial business models that have worked in the Spanish language markets within the U.S and Puerto Rico.

540464.title: Spanish American Cinema: Historical and Cultural Representations
540464.description: Cinema and literature as vehicles to analyze Spanish America historical and cultural realities such as stratification, gender and political practices. Taught in Spanish.

539350.title: Spanish Visual Representations of Cultural Transformations in the 20th Century
539350.description: Traces the development of modern Spanish society from the Second Republic of 1930 to 1983’s democracy. How films are texts capable of expressing social, historical or political issues and cultural changes. Conducted in Spanish.

539351.title: Spanish Literature to Neoclassicism
539351.description: Spanish literature from its beginnings to 1700. Representative works of each genre. Conducted in Spanish.

539352.title: Spanish-American Literature to Modernismo
539352.description: Spanish-American literature to modernismo. Conducted in Spanish. (LTAM 440 and SPAN 440 are the same course.)

539353.title: Spanish-American Literature Since Modernismo
539353.description: Spanish-American literature from modernismo to the present. Conducted in Spanish. (LTAM 441 and SPAN 441 are the same course.)

539354.title: Spanish Literature Since Neoclassicism
539354.description: Representative works of Spanish literature from 1700 to the present. Conducted in Spanish.

539355.title: Spanish Phonology and Dialectology
539355.description: Phonology of Spanish, specifically, the sound system, suprasegmentals and connected speech. Description and analysis of the dialectal varieties of Spanish. Conducted in Spanish.

539356.title: Spanish Morphology and Syntax
539356.description: Analytical procedures of general linguistics as applied to Spanish word and sentence structure. Conducted in Spanish.

539357.title: Spanish/English Bilingualism and Language Contact
539357.description: Comprehensive study of topics related to Spanish-English Bilingualism and language contact. Analyze the linguistic situation of the Hispanic groups in the United States within psycholinguistic, grammatical and sociolinguistic theoretical frames. Conducted in Spanish.

541187.title: Foundations of Translation
541187.description: The underpinnings of translation as an academic and professional field. Overview of theoretical frameworks under which translation is studied as a cognitive, sociocultural and ethical enterprise.

541188.title: Practice in Translation I
541188.description: Key theoretical concepts. Practical experience with the particularities of, and challenges posed by, translating commercial, cultural, financial and literary texts.

541189.title: Practice in Translation II
541189.description: Review key theoretical concepts and gain practical experience with the particularities of, and challenges posed by translating legal, medical, political, scientific and technical texts.

539358.title: Senior Seminar: Topics in Spanish Peninsular Literature
539358.description: Selected topics of the literature of Spain. Subject matter will change. May be repeated once for credit. Conducted in Spanish.

541147.title: Senior Seminar: Topics in Spanish Linguistics
541147.description: Selected topics in Spanish linguistics. Subject matter will change. May be repeated once for credit. Conducted in Spanish.

539359.title: Senior Seminar: Topics in Spanish-American Literature
539359.description: Selected topics of the literature of Spanish America. Subject matter will change. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Conducted in Spanish.

539360.title: Independent Study
539360.description: Supervised research projects in Spanish language, literature, culture, linguistics or business. May be repeated  for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

541190.title: Research and Teaching Methods in Spanish
541190.description: Provides a foundation in approaches, methods and materials for graduate-level research in Hispanic linguistics, literatures and cultures; and for teaching Spanish as a foreign language from the perspectives of second language acquisition research.

539361.title: Graduate Seminar: Advanced Structure and Style
539361.description: Transformational analysis of Spanish syntactic structures; classic approach to grammar; analysis of style in different contemporary writers, following a linguistic approach. Complemented with exercises and translations from English to Spanish. Conducted in Spanish.

540250.title: Early Modern Trans-Atlantic Encounters: Spain and the Americas
540250.description: Transatlantic literature, emphasizing representatives of exchanges, clashes and cultural reactions that arose. Analyze literary works, theoretical texts and cultural events that shape and reflect the power dynamics of transatlantic crossing.

539362.title: Graduate Seminar: Historical Linguistics
539362.description: Principles of historical linguistics as seen through the evolution of Classical Latin (phonology, morphology, syntax and lexicon) into contemporary Spanish. Conducted in Spanish.

539363.title: Graduate Seminar: Spanish Poetry
539363.description: Chronological overview of Peninsular poetry with special attention on specific authors and movements. Conducted in Spanish.

539364.title: Graduate Seminar: Spanish-American Poetry
539364.description: Chronological overview of Spanish-American poetry from 1888 (Latin American Modernism) to Vanguardist and present day poetry and “Anti-Poetry.” Conducted in Spanish.

539365.title: Graduate Seminar: Spanish-American Novel
539365.description: Historical overview of the development of the Spanish- American novel from the Colonial period (picaresque) to the Modern Experimental Novel. Conducted in Spanish.

538800.title: Group Process and Membership
538800.description: Didactic and experiential overview of stages of group development, impact of members on group identity, group member and leader issues. Survey various counseling groups. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Credit/No Credit only.

538801.title: Human Services Management
538801.description: Issues in administration and management of human services in community agencies. Assessing client needs, designing human service delivery systems, program budgeting, marketing strategies, accountability and improving program management.

538802.title: Contemporary Issues in the Human Services
538802.description: Systematic study and theory, research findings and intervention strategies related to contemporary issues faced by paraprofessional human service workers. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 9 units.

538803.title: Child Abuse and the Human Services
538803.description: Introduction to types and symptoms of abuse, assessment techniques, legal and ethical issues, family dynamics pertaining to children, adolescents and adults abused as children. Networking and referral, utilizing community resources and prevention.

538804.title: Physiological Effects of Alcohol and Other Drugs
538804.description: Pharmacological actions of drugs of abuse and how these relate to the physiological, psychological and behavioral effects of such drugs. Properties of recreational, “street” drugs and of prescription drugs that lead to abuse and/or dependence are covered. Not available for use on a graduate study plan.

538805.title: Drug Abuse Prevention and Early Intervention
538805.description: History, theories and models in the drug prevention field. Theoretical foundations and conceptual frameworks that have been used in the field will be presented. Major research and evaluation outcomes on the effectiveness of prevention strategies. Not available for use on a graduate study plan.

538806.title: Dynamics of Substance Abuse Treatment in Families
538806.description: Explore and apply methods of assisting significant others, organizations and communities to understand, treat and prevent substance abuse and dependence. Students develop practice strategies that will prepare them to deliver services at the micro, meso and macro levels. Not available for use on a graduate study plan.

538807.title: Co-Occurring Disorders: Assessment, Treatment and Referral
538807.description: Concepts, definitions and features of co-occurring mental disorders and substance-related disorders in individuals seen in human services settings; includes screening, assessment, case management and service delivery for such individuals. Not applicable to graduate degree requirements.

538809.title: Persons with Disabilities and Human Services Community Support Systems
538809.description: A diversity model approach to human service practice for persons with disabilities. Societal and professional stereotypes; disability culture; disability groupings; guidelines for practice with persons with disabilities; systems and community supports for persons with disabilities.

538811.title: Theory and Practice of Group Counseling
538811.description: Critical evaluation of 10 contemporary theoretical approaches to group counseling, as well as issues in group work. Applying theories and techniques to actual group situations.

541327.title: Integrating Acting and Psychodrama Exercises in Human Services
541327.description: Introduction to basic acting and psychodrama techniques designed to encourage self-awareness and promote growth and healing in future clients. Integrates acting exercises into counseling theories and techniques that challenge established behavioral and psychological patterns.

538810.title: Human Services Delivery to Latinos
538810.description: Theory, research findings and intervention strategies related to contemporary issues faced by paraprofessional human service workers in dealing with Latino populations. How to best deliver services in mental health, social welfare, and educational agencies.

538812.title: Evaluation of Human Services Programs
538812.description: Making program objectives measurable; determining appropriate methodology and techniques to evaluate effectiveness, efficiency and process variables; practical problems of program evaluation.

538813.title: Human Services Policy and Practice
538813.description: Relationship between policy and practice. Problem of inequities and inequalities in the distribution of resources through social policies and social welfare programs. How policy impacts service delivery to disenfranchised groups.

538814.title: Case Analysis and Intervention Techniques
538814.description: Psychodynamic principles of evaluation, diagnosis and intervention; techniques of counseling appropriate to diverse populations; application of a psychoanalytic perspective to the diagnostic categories of the DSM.

538815.title: Practicum in Group Leadership
538815.description: Supervised experience as a group leader. Approaches and techniques of group leadership. May be used as a substitute for HUSR 396, HUSR 495 or HUSR 496 with coordinator approval. May be repeated for a maximum of six units. Human Services majors and minors must earn a “C” (2.0) or better.

541123.title: HHD Peer Mentoring Academy
541123.description: New and experienced mentors will explore interdisciplinary mentorship with peer mentor service. Expand knowledge of resources to overcome barriers to college success. Enhance communication, cultural competency, leadership, motivational, goal achievement, personal management and student success skills. Requires recommendation to continue a second semester of mentorship by 399 instructor.

538816.title: Fieldwork Seminar
538816.description: Students participate in 120 hours of service at an approved agency, 8 hours per week. Classroom analysis of agency experience focusing on skills and techniques of human service workers and organizational analysis.

540891.title: Fieldwork
540891.description: Supervised fieldwork in one or more human service agencies for a minimum of eight hours per week. One or more sections may be offered in any online format. Credit/No Credit only.

538817.title: Internship Seminar
538817.description: Supervised internship in a community service agency in area of specialization. Seminar consists of group supervision and discussion of cases. Letter grade only. Internship experience consisting of 120 hours with a minimum of 8 hours per week during the semester.

540892.title: Internship
540892.description: Requires 120 hours of supervised internship experience in one or more human service agencies in one semester. May be taken for a maximum of three units. Credit/No Credit only. One or more sections may be offered in any online format.

538818.title: Independent Study
538818.description: Individual research project, either library or field, under the direction of a faculty member. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units; only three units in one semester. Requires approval of coordinator, consent of instructor.

540777.title: Leadership in Human Services Capstone Course
540777.description: Requires an original capstone project demonstrating the culmination of knowledge gained in the program and independent thinking. Identify a leadership need within an identified agency and develop a strategic plan addressing that need.
